{{Infobox company | name = Retail Council of Canada | logo = Retail Council of Canada logo.png | founded = {{start date and age|1963}} | area_served = [[Canada]] | website = {{url|https://www.retailcouncil.org}} }}
The '''Retail Council of Canada''' was founded in 1963. It is a [[Canada|Canadian]] [[not-for-profit]] association representing more than 45,000 stores of all retail formats, including independent merchants, regional and national mass and specialty chains, and online merchants. It strives to be the voice of the retail industry "to advance, promote and protect the interests of our members through effective advocacy, communications and education."<ref>{{cite web|title=Retail Council of Canada: About us|url=http://www.retailcouncil.org/about|accessdate=25 February 2014}}</ref>
==Board of directors== * Chair - Peter Higgins, President & Chocolate Scientist, [[Purdy's Chocolates]] * Vice-Chair - * Treasurer - Greg Hicks, President, [[Canadian Tire]] * President & CEO, [[Diane J. Brisebois]]
===Members=== * [[Alain Baird]] - President & CEO, [[The Stitch It Group Inc.]] *[[Guy Breaumier]] - Executive Vice-President, [[Lowe's#Canada|Lowe's Canada]] *[[Troy Dunn (businessman)|Troy Dunn]] - Director of [[Apple Store|Retail]], [[Apple Inc.|Apple]] Canada * [[Bob Hakeem]] - Chief Operations Officer, [[Walmart Canada]] * [[Greg Hicks]] - President, [[Canadian Tire]] * [[Bob Ianson]] - Co-Owner, [[Heirloom Linens]] * [[Michael Medline]] - President & CEO, [[Sobeys|Sobeys Inc.]] * [[Clint Mahlman]] - Executive Vice-President & CEO, [[London Drugs]] * [[Misti Mussatto]] - President & CEO, [[Toy Jungle]] * [[Beth Newlands Campbell]] - President, [[Rexall Drugstore]] * [[Pietro Nenci]] - Vice-President, GMM Corporate Foods, [[Costco]] Canada * [[Gary Senecal]] - Chief Customer Officer, [[Loblaw Companies Limited]] * [[George Soleas]] - President & CEO, [[Liquor Control Board of Ontario]] * [[Melanie Teed-Murch]] - President, [[Toys "R" Us#North America|Toys "R" Us]] Canada *[[Ron Wilson (businessman)|Ron Wilson]] - President & Chief Operating Officer, [[Best Buy]] Canada
==Awards== === Distinguished Canadian Retailer of the Year Award=== The Distinguished Canadian Retailer of the Year Award recognizes a retail leader that has led his/her company to outstanding business success and innovation and that has consistently demonstrated community commitment and support. The recipient is seen as a role model because of his/her exceptional leadership within the corporation, in the retail industry in Canada and in the community at large, through personal and/or corporate philanthropic activities. While years of service within the company are not a prerequisite, the individual's term as chief executive officer must commensurate with the company's outstanding success. The individual must be widely respected throughout the industry for his/her achievements and the corporation he/she represents must be seen as a leader in the business community.<ref>{{cite web|title=Retail Council of Canada: Awards of Distinction|url=http://www.storeconference.ca/awards-of-distinction|accessdate=25 February 2014}}</ref>
*2013-[[Stephen Wetmore]], [[Canadian Tire Corporation]] *2012-Brian Hill, [[Aritzia]] *2011-[[Heather Reisman]], [[Indigo Books & Music]] *2010-[[Steve Matyas]], [[Staples Canada]] *2009-[[Louise Wendling]], [[Costco Wholesale Canada Limited|Costco Canada]] *2008-[[Laurence Lewin]], [[La Senza|La Senza Corporation]] *2007-[[Mario Pilozzi]], [[Walmart Canada]] *2006-[[Edward Kennedy (Canadian business)|Edward Kennedy]], [[North West Company|The North West Company]] *2005-[[Annette Verschuren]], [[Home Depot Canada]] *2004-[[Wayne Sales]], [[Canadian Tire|Canadian Tire Corporation]] *2003-[[Wynne Powell]], [[London Drugs]] *2002-David Margolis, [[Winners|Winners Merchants Inc.]] *2001-[[John Forzani]], [[Forzani Group|The Forzani Group Ltd.]] *2000-[[Dave Ferguson (retailer)|Dave Ferguson]], [[Wal-Mart Canada|Walmart Canada]] *1999-[[Paul S. Walters]], [[Sears Canada|Sears Canada Inc.]] *1998-[[Stephen Bachand]], [[Canadian Tire|Canadian Tire Corporation Ltd.]] *1997-[[Richard Currie]], [[Loblaw Companies|Loblaw Companies Ltd.]] *1996-[[David Bloom (Canadian)|David Bloom]], [[Shoppers Drug Mart]] *1995-[[Allister Graham]], [[Oshawa Group]] *1994-[[Donald Beaumont]], [[Kmart|Kmart Canada]] *1993-[[George Ross Eaton]], [[Eaton's|The T. Eaton Company]] *1992-[[David Sobey]], [[Sobeys|Sobeys Inc.]] *1991-[[Harvey Webber]], [[The Smart Shop]] *1990-[[Dick Sharpe]], [[Sears Canada|Sears Canada Inc.]] *1989-[[Thomas J. Bata|Tom Bata]], [[Bata Shoes|Bata Retail]] *1988-[[Walter Hachborn]], [[Home Hardware]] *1987-[[Ray Wolfe]], [[Oshawa Group]] *1986-[[Murray Koffler]], [[Shoppers Drug Mart]] *1985-[[Abe Calp]], [[Calps New Brunswick]] *1984-[[Ed Mirvish]], [[Honest Ed's]] *1983 (Shared)-[[Jack Barrow]], [[Sears Canada|Sears Canada Inc.]] *1983 (Shared)-Tom Bolton, [[Dominion (supermarket)|Dominion Stores]]
===Lifetime achievement award=== The Lifetime Achievement Award recognizes a senior executive with a minimum of 25 consecutive years of retail service who has demonstrated outstanding business success and community service throughout his/her career.<ref>{{cite web|title=Retail Council of Canada: Lifetime Achievement Award|url=http://www.storeconference.ca/awards-of-distinction|accessdate=25 February 2014}}</ref>
*2013-(Not Awarded) *2012-[[Bill McEwan]], [[Sobeys Inc.]] *2011-(Not Awarded) *2010-[[Gordon Reid (businessman)|Gordon Reid]], [[Giant Tiger|Giant Tiger Stores Ltd.]] *2009-[[Réjean Dionne]], [[Aldo Group|Le Groupe Aldo Inc.]] *2008-Dr. [[Bill Comrie|William H. Comrie]], [[The Brick|The Brick Warehouse Corporation]] *2007-[[Walter J. Hachborn]], [[Home Hardware|Home Hardware Stores Ltd.]] *2006-[[Herschel Segal]], [[Le Chateau Inc.|Le Château Inc.]] *2005-[[Richard Currie]], [[Loblaw Companies|Loblaw Companies Ltd.]] *2004-(Not Awarded) *2003-[[Thomas J. Bata|Thomas J.]] and [[Sonja I. Bata]], [[Bata Shoes|Bata Shoe Organization]] *2002-(Not Awarded) *2001-[[Harry Rosen]], [[Harry Rosen Inc.]] *2000-[[Aldo Bensadoun]], [[Aldo (shoes)|The Aldo Group]] *1999-[[Ed Mirvish]], [[Honest Ed's]]
===Other Awards of Distinction=== *Canadian Retail Hall of Fame
===Excellence in Retailing Awards=== * Corporate & Social Responsibility * E-Commerce * Energy & Environmental Sustainability * Health, Safety & Wellness * In-Store * Merchandising * Loss Prevention * Marketing & Communications * Store Design * Talent Development * Technology

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2014}} {{Use Australian English|date=March 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Royce Abbey | image = Royce Abbey photo.png | caption = | birth_name = Albert Henry Royce Abbey | birth_date = {{Birth date|1922|6|8|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Footscray, Victoria]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|2014|2|20|1922|6|8|df=y}} | death_place = [[Melbourne, Victoria]] | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | residence = | nationality = [[Australia]]n | other_names = | known_for = President of Rotary International | education = | employer = Dural Leeds, [[Hunter Douglas]] | occupation = Businessman | title = | salary = | networth = | height = | weight = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | boards = | religion = | spouse = Jean Abbey (nee Jean Armstrong) | partner = | children = | parents = | relatives = | signature = | website = }}'''Royce Abbey''' (8 June 1922 – 20 February 2014) was an [[Australia]]n who was President of [[Rotary International]] in 1988-89.<ref name=Henningham1>Henningham, P. (2007). Royce Abbey: The Boy, the Soldier, the Businessman, the Rotarian Leader. Parramatta: RDU Books.</ref>
==Career== Royce Abbey was educated at state primary and secondary schools in [[Footscray, Victoria]]. When he left school in his mid-teens he worked as a shoeshine boy and messenger at a shoe shop and then in a real estate agency. In 1941, he enlisted in the [[Australian Army]] and was deployed in [[New Guinea]] and [[New Britain]] during [[World War 2]]. He was awarded a [[Distinguished Service Medal (Australia)]] for bravery and leadership during fighting. He was later commissioned as a Lieutenant.<ref name="Henningham1"/> <ref name=Abbey>Abbey, D. (2014). Rotary leader who put his life and soul into everything he did. Sydney Morning Herald, 14 March 2014Parramatta: RDU Books.</ref><ref name=RotaryAustralia>{{cite web |url= http://rotaryaustralia.org.au/news/6804/remembering-royce-abbey?frm_id=4|title=Remembering Royce Abbey|author= Rotary Australia|accessdate=27 December 2017}}</ref>
After the war, he joined his brother in a family-owned window shades manufacturing business, Dural Leeds, which was later taken over by the multinational company [[Hunter Douglas]]. After 5 years as marketing director for Hunter Douglas, he established his own business, Abbey Marketing.<ref name="Henningham1"/><ref name="Abbey"/><ref name="RotaryAustralia"/>
==Community Service== Royce Abbey joined the Rotary Club of Essendon in 1954, becoming Club President in 1963-64 and District 280 (9800) Governor in 1969-70. He was elected to the [[Rotary International]] Board in 1976-77 and served as Vice-President in 1977-78. He was inaugural Chairman of the Board of [[Australian Rotary Health]] from 1982-1988.<ref name=Henningham2>Henningham, P. (2011). With Health in Mind: The Story of Australian Rotary Health. Parramatta: Australian Rotary Health.</ref> In 1988-89 he became President of [[Rotary International]]. His time as President included the continued development of the Polio Plus campaign for [[Poliomyelitis eradication]] and the re-establishment of Rotary Clubs in countries from the former [[Soviet Union]].<ref name="Henningham1"/><ref name="Abbey"/><ref name="RotaryAustralia"/>
Royce Abbey was involved in a number of other community service activities, including: <ref name="Henningham1"/> <ref name="Abbey"/> * Councillor, [[City of Essendon]], 1960-1963. * President, National Council of [[YMCA]]s of Australia, 1982-1986. * Life Governor, National Council of [[YMCA]]s of Australia. * Chairman and Trustee, Epworth Medical Foundation, 1990-2000. * Patron, Australians Against Child Abuse. * Board Member and Trustee, Centre for Molecular Biology and Medicine. * Member of the Board, Kidsafe Australia.
==Honours== Royce Abbey received the following honours:<ref name="Henningham1"/><ref name="Abbey"/><ref name="RotaryAustralia"/> * [[Distinguished Service Medal (Australia)]] (for gallantry), 1944. * [[Rotary Foundation]] Citation for Meritorious Service, 1976. * [[Queen Elizabeth II Silver Jubilee Medal]] (for youth services), 1977. * Member of the [[Order of Australia]], 1988. * Advance Australia Ambassador, 1989. * [[Victorian of the Year]], 1989. * Officer of the [[Order of Australia]], 2001. * Honoured as [[Victoria University, Australia|Victoria University]] Legend during the University’s 90 years celebration, 2006. * The Royce Abbey Room is named in his honour at [[International House (University of Melbourne)]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ihouse.unimelb.edu.au/external-bookings/event-spaces|title=Event Spaces |author=International House |accessdate=27 December 2017}}</ref> * The Royce and Jean Abbey Endowed Fund and the Vocational Scholarship were established by Rotary to finance agricultural and related scholarships that would assist the less-developed countries in the Asia-Pacific region.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://royceabbey.com|title=The Royce and Jean Abbey Endowed Fund and the Vocational Scholarship|author=Royce Abbey Website |accessdate=27 December 2017}}</ref> * [[Australian Rotary Health]] has named the Royce Abbey Postdoctoral Fellowship in his honour.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://australianrotaryhealth.org.au/home/funding-breakdown/|title=Funding breakdown 2017|author=Australian Rotary Health |accessdate=27 December 2017}}</ref>
== References == <references />
== External links == * [http://royceabbey.com Royce Abbey Website]]
<!--- Categories --->
{{DEFAULTSORT:Abbey, Royce}} [[Category:1922 births]] [[Category:Australian businesspeople]] [[Category:Rotary International leaders]] [[Category:2014 deaths]] [[Category:People from Victoria (Australia)]]

{{cleanup|reason=The article needs to be wikified and have some links standardized.|date=April 2016}} {{Infobox company | name = Röchling Group | logo = Logo_Röchling.svg | type = [[SE & Co. KG]] | foundation = 1822 | location = [[Mannheim]], [[Germany]] | key_people = * Hanns-Peter Knaebel, CEO * Erwin Doll, co-chairman * Franz Lübbers * Steffen Rowold<ref name="unternehmen">County Court (Amtsgericht) Mannheim HRA 3529; online in [http://www.unternehmensregister.de/ Unternehmensregister].</ref> | num_employees = ca. 9700 | revenue = 1,8 [[billion|bln.]] [[Euro|EUR]] <ref name="Handelsblatt">{{cite news |last=Koenen |first=Jens |date=2018-06-08 |title=Hanns-Peter Knaebel. Ein Arzt für radikale Eingriffe |language=German |work=Handelsblatt |location= }}</ref> | industry = [[plastics engineering]] | homepage = http://www.roechling.com }}
'''Röchling SE & Co. KG''' is a [[plastics engineering]] company headquartered in [[Mannheim]], [[Baden-Württemberg]], Germany.<ref name="Handelsblatt" /> The company is divided in three divisions: Industry, Automotive and Medical. Currently Röchling employs 9700 people in 88 locations in 25 countries (North- and South America, Europe and Asia),<ref name="broschuere">{{cite web |url=https://www.roechling.com/fileadmin/downloads/Roechling_Group/Brochures/EN/Roechling_Imagebroschuere_2018_E.pdf |title= Röchling Group 2017/2018 Simply Closer |author= roechling.com |date= 2018-05-30 |website= |publisher= |access-date= 2018-06-05 |format= |pages=36–37 }}</ref> with annual sales of 1,8 billion euros in 2017.<ref name="Handelsblatt" />
== History ==
=== Beginnings ===
[[image:Carl_Röchling_2.jpg | frame type|right|200px | Carl Röchling (1827-1910) managed the company at the beginning of the 20th century alone for twenty years.]]
In 1822 Friedrich Ludwig Röchling founded a coal enterprise in [[Saarbrücken]]. After his death in 1836, his four nephews - Theodor, Ernst, Carl and Fritz - were left with the business, which was named Gebrüder Röchling KG. They began the industrial [[Coke (fuel)|coke]] and [[iron]] manufacturing in the midst of the 19th century.<ref>{{cite book |last=Nutzinger |first=D. Richard |date=1929 |title= Das Haus Röchling in [[Ludwigshafen]] a. Rh. 1849-1929. Bilder aus der Familien-, Orts- und Wirtschafts-Geschichte |trans-title= |url= |language=German |location=Ludwigshafen a.Rh. |publisher=Julius Waldkirch & Cie. |pages=11–16}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Nutzinger |first=D. Richard |date=1931 |title= 50 Jahre Röchling Völklingen |trans-title= |url= |language=German |location=Saarbrücken-Völklingen|publisher=Gebr. Hofer A.G. |pages=8–9}}</ref> After the death of his brothers Carl Röchling (1827-1910) managed the company alone for twenty years until the beginning of the 20th century.<ref>{{cite book |last=Seibold |first=Gerhard |date=2001 |title= Röchling. Kontinuität im Wandel |trans-title=Röchling. Continuity in Change |url= |language=German |location=Stuttgart |publisher= |isbn=3-7995-0101-0|pages=63}}</ref>
He then bought the [[Völklingen Ironworks]], which was run under the name Völklinger Eisenwerk Gebrüder Röchling. In 1860, the newly opened rail line near the production site, had a benefitial impact on the iron mill, as well as the addition of parts of [[Alsace|Elsass]] and [[Lorraine|Lothringen]] to the German empire after the war 1870/71.<ref>{{cite book |last=Seibold |first=Gerhard |date=2001 |title= Röchling. Kontinuität im Wandel |trans-title=Röchling. Continuity in Change |url= |language=German |location=Stuttgart |publisher= |isbn=3-7995-0101-0|pages=115–120}}</ref> <ref name="memo">{{cite web |url=http://www.memotransfront.uni-saarland.de/pdf/roechling_werke.pdf |title= Vom Baugewerbe über die Rüstung zum UNESCO-Weltkulturerbe Alte Völklinger Hütte |author= Gerhild Krebs |date=2002 |website= |publisher= |access-date= 2018-04-24 |format= PDF |pages=1–2 }}</ref>
After acquiring this [[iron mill]], which was given [[World Heritage site|World Heritage]] status in 1994 by [[UNESCO]], Röchling developed into the largest iron carrier manufacturer in Germany. In 1883, the first [[blast furnace]] was taken into operation in Völklingen.<ref name="huette">{{cite web |url=https://www.voelklinger-huette.org/weltkulturerbe-voelklinger-huette/geschichte/ |title= Die Geschichte der Völklinger Hütte |author= voelklinger-huette.org |date= |website= |publisher= |access-date= 2018-04-24 |format= |pages= }}</ref>
[[ Image: Röchlingsche_Eisen-_und_Stahlwerke.tif | frame type|right| 300px |View from the station in Völklingen onto the iron and steel works of the Röchling company (1910)]]
After the death of his father Carl, [[Hermann Röchling]] (1872-1955) became general director of the company in 1898. Under his supervision, the ironworks developed into a “modern” blast furnace factory, which could also satisfy the rising demand for high-grade steel.<ref name="memo" /><ref>{{cite book |last=Nutzinger |first=D. Richard |date=1931 |title= 50 Jahre Röchling Völklingen |trans-title= |url= |language=German |location=Saarbrücken-Völklingen|publisher=Gebr. Hofer A.G. |pages=51–52}}</ref>
=== World War I ===
Right after the beginning of [[World War I]], production of the iron works was adapted to meet the requirements of the war. On the company compound a factory was built to manufacture projectiles of almost any caliber for the [[artillery]]. In addition, a large part of the material needed for the production of the steel helmets of the german army was produced in Völklingen.<ref>{{cite book |last=Seibold |first=Gerhard |date=2001 |title= Röchling. Kontinuität im Wandel |trans-title=Röchling. Continuity in Change |url= |language=German |location=Stuttgart |publisher= |isbn=3-7995-0101-0|pages=168}}</ref>
[[Image:Edelstahl-Walzwerk_in_Völklingen.tif|frame type|right| 300px | High-grade steel mill in Völklingen (1920)]]
After the end of the war the victorious French powers withdrew the Röchling family's ownership of the iron mill in [[Thionville|Diedenhofen]] and the iron ore pits in Lothringen, as well as all locations in France. A [[Military justice|military court]] sentenced Hermann Röchling in his absence to ten years in prison for dismantling French operations in the occupied territories.<ref>{{cite book |last=Banken |first=Ralf |work=Neue Deutsche Biographie (NDB)|editor-first= |title=Röchling, Hermann |publisher=Duncker & Humblot |date=2003 |pages=705 |chapter= |isbn=3-428-11202-4}}</ref>
=== 1920 - 1945 ===
In the 1920s, the group included not only companies in the mining industry, but also banks and trading houses as well as extensive land and real estate.<ref>{{cite book |last=Seibold |first=Gerhard |date=2001 |title= Röchling. Kontinuität im Wandel |trans-title=Röchling. Continuity in Change |url= |language=German |location=Stuttgart |publisher= |isbn=3-7995-0101-0|pages=192–194}}</ref> Hermann Röchling acquired further companies,<ref name="NDB">{{cite book |last=Banken |first=Ralf |work=Neue Deutsche Biographie (NDB)|editor-first= |title=Röchling, Hermann |publisher=Duncker & Humblot |date=2003 |pages=703 |chapter= |isbn=3-428-11202-4}}</ref> including the “Berliner Holzveredelung GmbH” as the first plastics company<ref>{{cite book |last=Seibold |first=Gerhard |date=2001 |title= Röchling. Kontinuität im Wandel |trans-title=Röchling. Continuity in Change |url= |language=German |location=Stuttgart |publisher= |isbn=3-7995-0101-0|pages=196}}</ref> in 1922, from which today's Röchling Engineering Plastics SE & Co. KG developed, which was based in Haren, Emsland.<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title= 100 Jahre Röchling Kunststoff – Jubiläum nach bewegter Geschichte trans-title= 100 years Röchling Kunststoff - Jubilee after troubled history|url= |language= |work=Meppener Tagespost |location=Meppen|date=2016-06-25 |pages= 20}}</ref> Politically, the "patriarch"<ref>{{cite book |last=Plettenberg |first=Inge|work=|editor-last=Stadtverband |editor-first= Saarbrücken |title=Zehn statt Tausend Jahre. Die Zeit des Nationalsozialismus an der Saar (1935-1945) |publisher=Merziger|date=2003 |pages=60–77, 63 |chapter= Über die Beziehungen saarländischer Schwerindustrieller zum Nationalsozialismus |isbn=3-923754-06-X}}</ref> sat down for the reintegration of the Saarland, which has been under the [[League of Nations]] Mandate until 1935. In 1935, he joined the [[NSDAP]] and was an armor advisory council member of the Reich Ministry of War, in 1938 appointed “Wehrwirtschaftsführer” and in 1942 he was given the position of "Reich Commissioner for Iron and Steel in the Occupied Territories".<ref>{{cite book |last=Klee |first=Ernst |date=2003 |title= Das Personenlexikon im Dritten Reich. Wer war was vor und nach 1945? |url= |language=German |location=Frankfurt|publisher= S. Fischer |isbn=3-10-039309-0|pages=502}}</ref> During [[World War II|the Second World War]], the Saarland-based company produced weapons such as the „Röchling grenade“ in large numbers in its electric furnace facility.<ref>{{cite book |last=Plettenberg |first=Inge|work=|editor-last=Stadtverband |editor-first= Saarbrücken |title=Zehn statt Tausend Jahre. Die Zeit des Nationalsozialismus an der Saar (1935-1945) |publisher=Merziger|date=2003 |pages=66–67 |chapter= Über die Beziehungen saarländischer Schwerindustrieller zum Nationalsozialismus |isbn=3-923754-06-X}}</ref>
Because of industrial exploitation of the occupied territories, "increase of the war potential of the [[Nazi Germany|Third Reich]] and considerable role in the execution of the program of [[deportation]] for the purpose of [[Forced labour under German rule during World War II|forced labor]]"<ref>{{cite book |last= Militärregierung der Französischen Besatzungszone in Deutschland |first=Oberstes Gericht |date=1949 |title= Unterlagen zu den Röchling-Prozessen: Urteile des General-Gerichts und des Obersten Gerichts |url= |language=German |location=Mannheim |publisher= |isbn= |pages=44}}</ref> Hermann Röchling was senctenced by a French military court to a ten-year imprisonment plus asset expropriation in 1949 and was deprived of his [[Civil and political rights|civil rights]], but released after two years of imprisonment.<ref name="NDB" />
=== Second half of the 20th century ===
In 1956, the company bought [[Rheinmetall]] Berlin AG, the equipment supplier of the newly founded Bundeswehr.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.rheinmetall.com/en/rheinmetall_ag/group/corporate_history/125_jahre_rheinmetall_1/jahre_1946_bis_1/index.php |title= 125th anniversary of Rheinmetall – the years 1946 bis 1956 |last= |first= |date= |website= |publisher=Rheinmetall AG |access-date= 2018-06-08 |quote=}}</ref> The Völklingen iron works was under French tribunal administration until 1956, when it was returned to the Röchling family.<ref name="huette" /> In the same year, Ernst Röchling, a nephew of Hermann Röchling, became head of the company in Völklingen. In 1960 the company was divided into two holding companies: „Röchling Brothers KG“ (KG Gebr. Röchling) and “Industry Management Röchling GmbH”,<ref>{{cite book |last=Seibold |first=Gerhard |date=2001 |title= Röchling. Kontinuität im Wandel |trans-title=Röchling. Continuity in Change |url= |language=German |location=Stuttgart |publisher= |isbn=3-7995-0101-0|pages=307–308}}</ref> which was renamed Röchling Industry Management GmbH (RIV) in 1972. [23] It included all listed companies, including the investment in Rheinmetall AG.<ref>{{cite book |last=Seibold |first=Gerhard |date=2001 |title= Röchling. Kontinuität im Wandel |trans-title=Röchling. Continuity in Change |url= |language=German |location=Stuttgart |publisher= |isbn=3-7995-0101-0|pages=357}}</ref> It included all listed companies, including the investment in Rheinmetall AG.
The 1960s and 1970s were shaped by the coal crisis and the following [[steel crisis]] for the Röchling Group.<ref name="broschuere"/> The company responded to the decline in revenue in these areas with diversification,<ref>{{cite book |last=Seibold |first=Gerhard |date=2001 |title= Röchling. Kontinuität im Wandel |trans-title=Röchling. Continuity in Change |url= |language=German |location=Stuttgart |publisher= |isbn=3-7995-0101-0|pages=300–314}}</ref> and the complete withdrawal from the steel industry and the Saarland. In 1978 the “Völklinger Hütte” was sold to Arbed, today's Saarstahl AG.<ref name="huette" />
Instead, the Röchling Group acquired holdings and complete companies in the fields of [[mechanical engineering]], [[telecommunications]], [[electrical installation]], [[franking]] systems, [[measurement]] and control technology. With the acquisition of the Seeber Group and Sustaplast KG, the declared expansion of the plastics processing sector began in the 1980s.<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title= Röchling / Kunststoffbereich soll ausgebaut werden |url= |work=Handelsblatt |location= |date=1993-06-18 |pages=19 }}</ref>
=== 21st Century===
At the beginning of the 21st century, the conglomerate employed more than 41,000 people in more than 300 subsidiaries and associated companies<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title= Die Röchling-Gruppe – Familienclan herrscht über Mischkonzern |trans-title= The Röchling Group - Family Clan reigns diversified conglomerate |language=German |url= https://www.handelsblatt.com/archiv/die-roechling-gruppe-familienclan-herrscht-ueber-mischkonzern/2441382.html |work=Handelsblatt |location= |date=2004-11-24 | access-date=2018-04-26 }}</ref> and generated sales of around € 6.1 billion. The biggest source of revenue was the electronics and defense group, Rheinmetall, in which Röchling held a stake of 42.1 percent.<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title= Röchling stützt Strategie von Rheinmetall |trans-title= Röchling supports Strategy of Rheinmetall |language=German |work=Handelsblatt |location= |date=2001-06-01 | pages=14}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title= Durchwachsene Bilanz bei Röchling |trans-title= Röchling with mixed Results |language=German |work=Saarbrücker Zeitung |location= |date=2001-06-27 | pages=}}</ref>
According to the [[Manager Magazin]], the Röchling Group had "tangled" with the company's strong diversification and ramifications. The expansion of the subsidiary Rheinmetall under the controversial CEO Hans Brauner had increased sales, but brought no returns.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.manager-magazin.de/unternehmen/karriere/a-308583.html |title= Rüstige Alte, friedlicher Nachwuchs |trans-title= Sprightly old folks - Peaceful Offspring |language=German|last=Scheele |first=Martin |date=2004-08-09 |website= manager-magazin.de |publisher= |access-date=2018-04-24 |quote=}}</ref> Therefore, in 2001, Röchling decided a fundamental change of strategy under the new non-family director [[Georg Duffner]]: abandonment of the conglomerate and further expansion of the business unit plastics processing.<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title= Röchling setzt auf das Kunststoffgeschäft |trans-title= |language=German |work=Handelsblatt |location= |date=2004-06-11 | pages=14}}</ref> In 2004 Röchling sold its majority stake in Rheinmetall at a price of 570 million euros.<ref>{{cite news |last=Seidlitz |first=Frank |date=2004-11-30 |title= Nach 50 Jahren hat sich die Industriellenfamilie vom Rüstungskonzern getrennt – Aktien breit gestreut. Röchlings machen den Rheinmetall-Verkauf perfekt |trans-title= |work=Die Welt |location= |pages=15}}</ref> In 2005 the sale of [[Francotyp-Postalia]], a manufacturer of franking and inserting machines<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title= Röchling verkauft Francotyp-Postalia. Finanzinvestor Quadriga greift zu |trans-title= |language=German |work=Börsen-Zeitung |location= |date=2005-03-10 | pages=13}}</ref> and the deficit telecommunications company DeTeWe followed.<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title= Röchling setzt auf Kunststoffe |trans-title= |language=German |url= https://www.handelsblatt.com/unternehmen/industrie/ziel-vor-augen-roechling-setzt-auf-kunststoffe/2512172.html |work=Handelsblatt |location= |date=2005-06-10 | access-date=2018-04-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title= Röchling trennt sich auch von DeTeWe. Fokus auf Kunststoffe – Verlustbringer abgegeben |trans-title= |language=German |work=Börsen-Zeitung |location= |date=2005-07-15 | pages=11}}</ref>
During the conversion to a plastic producer, all family members withdrew from the operative core business in accordance with the [[shareholder]]s' resolution and moved to supervisory bodies.<ref>{{cite news |last=Müller |first=Anja |date=2017-10-16 |title= Wenn aus Nachfolgern Investoren werden |trans-title= |work=Handelsblatt |location= |pages=36}}</ref><ref name="familie">{{cite book |last1=Plate |first1=Markus |last2=Groth |first2=Torsten |last3=Ackermann |first3=Volker |title=Große Deutsche Familienunternehmen: Generationenfolge, Familienstrategie und Unternehmensentwicklung |publisher=Vandenhoeck & Ruprecht |date=2011 |pages=215 |chapter= Gebr. Röchling KG |isbn= 978-3525403389 |lastauthoramp=}}</ref> In 2001, Klaus Greinert, son-in-law of Richard Röchling and former managing director, joined the advisory board and became chairman of the family council. There he replaced Kurt Wigand Freiherr von Salmuth, who was a member of various family committees since 1964.<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title= Freiherr von Salmuth 70 |trans-title= |language=German |work=Börsen-Zeitung |location= |date=2001-01-20 | pages=14}}</ref> With Bernd Michael Hönle, who had been managing director since 1994, the last operationally active family member changed to the supervisory board in 2008.<ref name="familie" />
The restructuring started in 1978 into a pure plastics processor with the areas of high-performance plastics and automotive plastics was completed in 2006.<ref name="RNZ">{{cite news |last=Berlinghof |first=Harald |date=2014-12-03 |url=https://www.rnz.de/wirtschaft/wirtschaft-regional_artikel,-Wirtschaft-Regional-Roechling-bleibt-ein-Familienunternehmen-_arid,69166.html |title=Röchling bleibt ein Familienunternehmen |trans-title= Röchlings stays family business |language=German |work=Rhein-Neckar-Zeitung |location= |access-date=2018-06-11}}</ref> In 2006 the last electronics company and a cold rolling mill were sold, which brought the Röchling Group a profit increase.<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title= Röchling setzt ganz auf Kunststoffe. Weiter kleine Akquisitionen – Wachstum ohne Schulden – Wurzeln gekappt |trans-title= |language=German |work=Börsen-Zeitung |location= |date=2007-05-25 | pages=12}}</ref> In 2008, Röchling decided to produce engineering plastics as its third product division,<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title= Röchling baut neue Sparte auf. Technische Kunststoffe sollen drittes Bein werden – auf Akquisitionstour |trans-title= |language=German |work=Börsen-Zeitung |location= |date=2008-06-20 | pages=11}}</ref> and acquired its first medical device company.<ref name="Historie">{{cite web |url=https://www.roechling.com/roechling-group/history/ |title=History |last= |first= |date= |website=www.roechling.com |publisher= |access-date= 2018-04-24 |quote=}}</ref> In 2009 Röchling still had 56 subsidiaries instead of 327 at the time of the conglomerate.<ref>{{cite news |last=Stieber |first=Benno |date= 2009-04-01 |title= Weniger ist mehr |trans-title=Less is More |work=Financial Times |location= |pages=6–11}}</ref>
In 2011, sales exceeded the threshold of one billion euros, with Röchling employing around 6600 people worldwide.<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title= Röchling wächst zweistellig |trans-title= |language=German |work=Börsen-Zeitung |location= |date=2012-05-25 | pages=13}}</ref> In 2012, the Röchling Group invested more than 140 million euros and expanded in Brazil, India, Australia and China.<ref>{{cite news |last=Koenen |first=Jens |date= 2013-06-13 |title= Familie Röchling hilft in Venedig |trans-title= |work=Handelsblatt |location= |pages=19}}</ref>
This was followed in 2016 by a first production site in Mexico <ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.automobil-industrie.vogel.de/roechling-automotive-nimmt-erstes-werk-in-mexiko-in-betrieb-a-535516 |title= Röchling Automotive nimmt erstes Werk in Mexiko in Betrieb |last=Scheiner |first=Jens |date= 2016-05-20 |website= |publisher= |access-date=2018-04-24 |quote=}}</ref> and a joint venture in Japan.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.automobil-industrie.vogel.de/roechling-verstaerkt-partnerschaft-in-japan-a-548284 |title= Röchling verstärkt Partnerschaft in Japan |last=Otto |first=Christian |date=2016-08-30 |website= |publisher= Automobil-Industrie |access-date=2018-04-24 |quote=}}</ref> In 2014, the company was renamed Röchling SE & Co. KG.<ref name="unternehmen" /> In 2016 former CEO Georg Duffner was replaced by Ludger Bartels <ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title= Bartels neuer Vorstandschef bei Röchling |trans-title= |language=German |work=Meppener Tagespost |location= |date= 2016-01-22 | pages=}}</ref> and the divisions reorganized: In addition to the existing automotive division, the previous second division - "High Performance Plastics" - was renamed "Industry" and the "Medical Division" was founded.<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title= Röchling investiert kräftig |trans-title= |language=German |work=Meppener Tagespost |location= |date= 2016-06-25 | pages=20}}</ref>
== Enterprise ==
===Management ===
Company decisions are determined by the Shareholders' Committee, the [[Advisory Board]] and the Röchling Management Board. In 2014, more than 200 members of the Röchling family belonged to the shareholders.<ref name="RNZ" /> While the tasks of the advisory board correspond to a supervisory board,<ref name="familie"/> the Röchling Management Board is responsible for strategy development and operational implementation. In addition to the Executive Board, managers from the Industrial, Automotive, Medical and Economic Regions divisions are represented here.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.roechling.com/roechling-group/roechling-management-board/ |title= Röchling Management Board |last= |first= |date= |website=www.roechling.com |publisher= |access-date= 2018-06-08 |quote=}}</ref>
Johannes Freiherr von Salmuth, a direct descendant of Friedrich Röchling in the sixth generation, took over as chair of the supervisory bodies: In 2008 (Shareholders' Committee) and in 2010 (Advisory Council). His deputies are also two Röchling family members, Bernd Michael Hönle (Shareholders' Committee) and Carl Peter Thürmel (Advisory Council).<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title= Johannes Freiherr von Salmuth kontrolliert Röchling |trans-title= |language=German |work=Börsen-Zeitung |location= |date= 2011-01-20 | pages=7}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.plastverarbeiter.de/12098/stabwechsel-im-beirat-der-roechling-gruppe/|title= Stabwechsel im Beirat der Röchling-Gruppe |last= |first= |date= 2011-01-19 |website=www.plastverarbeiter.de |publisher= |access-date= 2018-04-24 |quote=}}</ref> Hanns-Peter Knaebel has been CEO of the Röchling Group since 2018 and is responsible for the Medical division. He replaced the retired Ludger Bartels.<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title= Knaebel Chef des Vorstands bei Röchling |trans-title= |language=German |work=Meppener Tagespost |location= |date= 2017-08-23 | pages=16}}</ref>
'''Röchling Management Board'''<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.roechling.com/fileadmin/downloads/Roechling_Group/Brochures/EN/Roechling_Imagebroschuere_2018_E.pdf|title= Röchling Group - Simply Closer |last= |first= |date= |website=www.roechling.com |publisher=Röchling Group |access-date= 2018-06-05 |pages=74}}</ref>
* Hanns-Peter Knaebel (CEO) * Erwin Doll (Co-Chairman) * Franz Lübbers * Steffen Rowold * Joachim Brunswicker * Lewis H. Carter * Heinz Dirksen * Gerhard Neidinger * Uwe Kassens * Andrea Rocca * Mario Frericks * Evelyn Thome
Advisory Board ('''Beirat''')<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.roechling.com/fileadmin/downloads/Roechling_Group/Brochures/EN/Roechling_Imagebroschuere_2018_E.pdf |title= Röchling Group 2017/2018 Simply Closer |author= roechling.com |date= 2018-05-30 |website= |publisher= |access-date= 2018-06-05 |format= |pages=75 }}</ref>
* Johannes Freiherr von Salmuth (Chairman) * Carl Peter Thürmel (Co-Chairman) * Günter von Au * Dorothée Anna Deuring * Georg Duffner * Gregor Greinert * Bernd Michael Hönle * Gerd Kleinert * Klaus Nehring
=== Business areas ===
As of 2016 the Röchling Group is divided into the three divisions: industry, automotive and medical division.<ref>The consolidated financial statement of fiscal year 2017 is published online [http://www.unternehmensregister.de/ Unternehmensregister].</ref> Nearly 40 percent of sales are generated in Germany, 31 percent in the rest of Europe, followed by America (20 percent) and Asia (10 percent).<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.roechling.com/uk/industrial/ |title= About the Group |last= |first= |date= |website=www.roechling.com |publisher=Röchling Group |access-date= 2018-04-24 |pages=}}</ref> In Germany the Röchling Group operates 24 locations: [[Arnstadt, [[Bad Grönenbach]]-Thal, [[Brensbach]], [[Gernsbach]], [[Haren, Germany|Haren]], [[Ingolstadt]], [[Cologne|Köln]], Peine]], [[Lahnstein]], [[Laupheim]], [[Lützen]], [[Mainburg]], [[Mannheim]], [[Nentershausen, Rhineland-Palatinate|Nentershausen]], [[Neuhaus am Rennweg]], [[Roding, Germany|Roding]], [[Ruppertsweiler]], [[Rüsselsheim am Main]], [[Stuttgart]], [[Troisdorf]], [[Wackersdorf]], [[Weidenberg]], [[Wolfsburg]] and [[Worms, Germany|Worms]].<ref name="broschuere" />
'''Industry'''
The product range of the Industrial division comprises semi-finished and finished parts made of duroplastic and thermoplastic materials. Semifinished products include plates, round, hollow and flat bars, molded parts and profiles.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.roechling.com/us/industrial/ |title= About the Group - Industry |last= |first= |date= |website=www.roechling.com |publisher=Röchling Group |access-date= 2018-04-24 |pages=}}</ref> Finished parts include machined thermoplastic components for industrial applications.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.roechling.com/industrial/products/thermoplastics/semi-finished-products |title=Semi-finished products made of thermoplastics|last= |first= |date= |website=www.roechling.com |publisher=Röchling Group |access-date= 2018-04-24 |pages=}}</ref> This division employs 3511 people in 40 locations.<ref name="broschuere-2">{{cite web |url=https://www.roechling.com/fileadmin/downloads/Roechling_Group/Brochures/EN/Roechling_Imagebroschuere_2018_E.pdf |title=Röchling Group 2017/2018 Simply Closer |last= |first= |date= |website=www.roechling.com |publisher=Röchling Group |access-date= 2018-05-30 |pages=23}}</ref>
'''Automotive'''
The Automotive division employs over 5,400 people in 43 company locations.<ref name="broschuere-2"/> It supplies automotive manufacturers and system suppliers with plastic applications in the aerodynamics, powertrain and new mobility sectors. According to Röchling, declared goals are the reduction of emissions, weight and fuel consumption in the automotive industry.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.roechling.com/automotive/about-roechling-automotive/company-profile/ |title= Company profile |last= |first= |date= |website=www.roechling.com |publisher=Röchling Group |access-date= 2018-04-24 |pages=}}</ref>
'''Medical'''
The Medical division manufactures plastic components for customers in the medical and pharmaceutical industries and is divided into the areas of pharmaceutical, diagnostics, surgery and life science. The products are used in drug delivery systems, primary packaging, surgical instruments and diagnostic disposables.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.roechling.com/medical/|title= Röchling Medical |last= |first= |date= |website=www.roechling.com |publisher=Röchling Group |access-date= 2018-04-24 |pages=}}</ref> This division has four locations with 718 employees.<ref name="broschuere-2" />
== Röchling charity foundation ==
The non-profit Röchling Stiftung GmbH was founded in 1990. It is financed by the start-up capital provided by the entrepreneurial family, by limited partnerships granted and inherited from shareholders in Röchling SE & Co. KG, investment income and cash [[donation]]s.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.roechling-stiftung.de/en/about-us/ |title=Business family with tradition |last= |first= |date= |website=www.roechling-stiftung.de |publisher=Röchling Stiftung |access-date= 2018-04-24 |pages=}}</ref> The [[Foundation (nonprofit)|foundation]] focuses on the field of [[plastics pollution|plastics and the environment]] and wants to make a contribution to reducing the environmental impact of plastics worldwide.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.roechling-stiftung.de/en/eligibility-criteria/ |title=Eligibility Criteria|last= |first= |date= |website=www.roechling-stiftung.de |publisher=Röchling Stiftung |access-date= 2018-04-24 |pages=}}</ref> To this end, the foundation supports scientific research into new concepts for reducing plastic waste and improving recycling, as well as projects in sustainable development education.
The foundation has sponsored collection centers for plastic waste in Mumbai, India,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.dandc.eu/en/article/how-local-initiative-encouraging-waste-pickers-mumbai-contribute-date-plastics-recycling |title=A system for collecting waste |last=Möllenstädt |first=Oliver |date= 2016-05-10 |website= www.dandc.eu |publisher= |access-date= 2018-04-24 |pages=}}</ref> and financed the construction of the "Manatee" waste collection vessel owned by “One Earth - One Ocean” for cleansing the oceans.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.sueddeutsche.de/muenchen/fuerstenfeldbruck/umwelt-aus-einem-seehamster-einen-elefanten-machen-1.3471185 |title= Abfall sammeln mit System |last=Götte |first=Karl Wilhelm |date= 2017-04-20 |website= |publisher=Süddeutsche Zeitung|access-date= 2018-04-24 |pages=}}</ref> In 2018 the foundation will support the development of the "Manatee" into a recycling system at sea,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://oneearth-oneocean.com/en/the-solution/ |title= The Solution - Concept / Technology |last= |first= |date= |website= |publisher=One Earth - One Ocean|access-date= 2018-06-08 |pages=}}</ref> exploration of a possibly plastic-decomposing insect larva<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.roechling-stiftung.de/en/2017/06/30/interview-with-dr-federica-bertocchini/ |title= Interview with Dr. Federica Bertocchini |last= |first= |date=2017-06-30 |website= |publisher=Röchling Stiftung|access-date= 2018-04-24 |pages=}}</ref> along with collection and recycling of plastic waste in the [[Ganges delta]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://soceo.de/development/combating-plastic-pollution/ |title= Combating Plastic Pollution in the Sundarbans |last= |first= |date= |website= |publisher=Soceo |access-date= 2018-06-08 |pages=}}</ref>
== External links ==
* [https://www.roechling.com/us/ Homepage roechling.com] * [http://www.voelklinger-huette.org/ Völklinger Hütte] * [http://www.deutsche-biographie.de/sfz106111.html Röchling in „Deutsche Biografie“]

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=September 2018}} {{Infobox company | logo = Smera Logo.png | name = SMERA Ratings Ltd | type = [[Public company|Public]] | foundation = 2005 <ref>{{cite web|author=Our Regional Bureau / Chennai 6 September 2005 |url=http://www.business-standard.com/india/news/fm-launches-sme-rating-agency/209810/ |title=FM launches SME Rating Agency |publisher=Business-standard.com |date=2005-09-06 |accessdate=2011-03-01}}</ref> | location = [[Mumbai]], [[Maharashtra]], [[India]] | num_employees = | key_people = | industry = | products = | services = [[Credit rating|Ratings]], [[Research]] and [[Financial adviser|Advisory]] | revenue = | parent = | subsid = | net_income= | homepage = {{url|www.smera.in}} }}
'''SMERA Ratings Ltd''' (SMERA) is a full service [[credit rating agency]] exclusively set up for micro, small and medium enterprises (MSME) in [[India]] and has grown to rate SME, mid & large corporate . It provides ratings which enable MSME, SMEs,Corporates to raise bank loans at competitive rates of interest.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://finmin.nic.in/the_ministry/dept_fin_services/banking/smerafi.asp|title=Financial Institutions and others |publisher=Finance Ministry|date= |accessdate=2011-02-26}}</ref> However, its registration with [[Securities and Exchange Board of India]] (SEBI), as a Credit Rating Agency and accreditation by [[Reserve Bank of India]] (RBI), in September 2012 as an external credit assessment institution (ECAI) to rate bank loan ratings under Basel II guidelines has paved way for SMERA to rate/grade various instruments such as: IPO, NCDs, Commercial Papers, Bonds, Security Receipts, Fixed Deposits etc. In addition to this, RBI has told that Banks may use ratings of bank facilities (Bank Loan Ratings) from SMERA, to assign risks to loans for the purpose of computing capital adequacy requirements.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2012-09-13/news/33817065_1_standardised-approach-risk-weights-smera# |title=Archived copy |access-date=23 February 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131122202248/http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2012-09-13/news/33817065_1_standardised-approach-risk-weights-smera# |archive-date=22 November 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
== History == The agency was founded in 2005 by [[Small Industries Development Bank of India]] (SIDBI),<ref>{{cite web|author=Wednesday, 28 March 2007 at 0044 hrs IST |url=http://www.financialexpress.com/news/sme-rating-agency-to-expand-operations-in-northern-region/195188/0 |title=SME rating agency to expand operations in northern region |publisher=Financialexpress.com |date=2007-03-28 |accessdate=2011-03-01}}</ref> Dun & Bradstreet Information Services India Private Limited ([[D&B]]) and several leading Govt., Public, Private and MNC banks in the country.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=40826425 |title=SME Rating Agency of India Ltd.: Private Company Information|publisher= BusinessWeek |date= |accessdate=2011-02-21}}</ref>
== Achievements ==
1) SMERA has pioneered SME ratings in the country and has till date completed over 49,000 ratings across sectors and geographies on a pan – India basis. SMERA Ratings have gained wide acceptability and are now an integral part of the risk assessment process within the lending and investing community.
2) The Association of Development Financing Institutions in Asia and the Pacific (ADFIAP) has awarded SIDBI with "Outstanding Development Project Award" for setting up SMERA. The award was given under the SME Development Category during the 30th ADFIAP Annual Meeting held on 10 May 2007 at [[Hanoi]], [[Vietnam]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.financialexpress.com/news/smera-gets-adfiap-award/200935/1|title=SMERA gets ADFIAP Award|publisher=Financial Express|date= |accessdate=2011-02-26}}</ref>
3) SMERA has been registered under [[Securities and Exchange Board of India]] (Credit Rating Agencies) Regulations, 1999 making it only the sixth rating agency in India to rate issues such as IPO, bonds, commercial papers, security receipts and others.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/industry-and-economy/banking/article1506262.ece|title=SMERA receives SEBI registration|publisher=Business Line|date=|accessdate=2011-04-08|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110424051722/http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/industry-and-economy/banking/article1506262.ece#|archive-date=24 April 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
4) SMERA is also accredited by Reserve Bank of India (RBI) as an external credit assessment institution (ECAI) to rate bank loan ratings under Basel II guidelines.
== References == {{Reflist}}
==External links== * {{Official website|http://smera.in/Aboutus.aspx}} * [http://smera.in/smerating.aspx SMERA ratings] * [http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/news-by-industry/banking/finance/banking/indian-bank-inks-mou-with-sme-rating-agency-of-india/articleshow/2746904.cms Indian Bank inks MoU with SME Rating Agency of India] * [http://www.business-standard.com/india/news/sme-rating-agency-to-open-four-more-offices-in-north/279085/ SME rating agency to open four more offices in North] * [http://www.financialexpress.com/news/fm-to-unveil-rating-agency-for-sme-today/133577/0 FM to unveil rating agency for SME today]
[[Category:Financial services companies based in Mumbai]] [[Category:Credit rating agencies in India]] [[Category:Companies established in 2005]] [[Category:Organizations related to small and medium-sized enterprises]]

revision.text:
'''Salah Abdulla Nooruddin Nooruddin''' ({{lang-ar|صلاح عبد الله نور الدين نور الدين}}; born 1963) is [[Bahrain]]i [[Businessman]] and the former chairman of [[Leeds United Football Club]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23127891 | title=Leeds United: Salah Nooruddin becomes chairman | publisher=BBC | date=1 July 2013 | accessdate=2 July 2013}}</ref><ref>http://www.express.co.uk/sport/football/419605/Leeds-United-s-new-chairman-speaks-exclusively-to-the-Daily-Express</ref>
Bahraini-based businessman Salah Nooruddin, CEO of Envest Limited, initially bought a 3.33% stake in LUFC Holding Limited following the takeover of Leeds United by [[GFH Capital]]<nowiki> - an </nowiki>[[Islamic]] [[investment bank]] with headquarters in [[Bahrain]]. Nooruddin was initially appointed vice-chairman<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.yorkshireeveningpost.co.uk/sport/leeds-united/latest-whites-news/salah-nooruddin-named-as-new-leeds-united-vice-chairman-1-5692630 | title=Salah Nooruddin named as new Leeds United vice-chairman | publisher=Yorkshire Evening Post | date=21 May 2013 | accessdate=2 July 2013}}</ref> on 21 May 2013 but following the end of [[Ken Bates]]' tenure as chairman Nooruddin became chairman on 1 July 2013.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.motforum.com/article.php?page=28998 | title=A good day for Leeds United | publisher=Marching on Together | date=1 July 2013 | accessdate=28 August 2013}}</ref> It was later revealed that he had increased his stake in the club to 10%.
In early 2014 GFH Capital sold their majority stake in the club to Italian Businessman Massimo Cellino who then became majority shareholder by 75% this means GFH Capitol would only retain a 5% stake in the club while Nooruddin would retain a 10% stake through his company Envest Ltd while he would also look after the 10% stake in the club owned by the International Investment Bank.
In 2014 Nooruddin was removed as club chairman by new owner Massimo Cellino but would remain on the board of directors until April 2014 when he resigned from the board.
<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.motforum.com/article.php?page=29248 | title=The Takeover That Keeps on Giving | publisher=Marching on Together | date=15 August 2013 | accessdate=28 August 2013}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Nooruddin, Salah}} [[Category:1963 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Chairmen of Leeds United F.C.]] [[Category:Bahraini businesspeople]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} {{Use British English|date=September 2013}} '''Steffan Luke Aquarone''' is a UK entrepreneur in the film and technology sectors. His projects involve collaboration between large groups of people with a common interest<ref>Roxborough, Scott [http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/how-an-english-village-bankrolled-187989 "How an English Village Bankrolled 'A Tortoise in Love'"], ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'', 12 May 2011. Retrieved on 9 June 2012.</ref> and are often crowd-source financed,<ref>MIPDoc 2011, [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SqhpzXYO_D4 "Crowdsourcing: the frontier of documentary and funding"], Cannes, 3 April 2011. Retrieved on 9 June 2012.</ref> the most notable example being feature-film ''[[Tortoise in Love]]'' which was made by a village in Oxfordshire.<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/film/cannes-film-festival/8511550/British-comedy-funded-by-village-residents-to-show-at-Cannes.html "British comedy funded by village residents to show at Cannes"], ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' 13 May 2011. Retrieved 9 June 2012.</ref>
In 2014, Aquarone was named by the Daily Mirror as one of the Top 20 most influential media figures under 30<ref>[https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/technology-science/technology/snapchat-founder-evan-spiegel-tops-4750836 "Top 20 most influential media figures under 30"], ''[[Daily Mirror]]'' 4 December 2014. Retrieved 17 February 2017.</ref>.
==Education== Aquarone was educated at home as a member of [[Education Otherwise]] until the age of 12, before attending [[Norwich School (independent_school)|Norwich School]]. He then read Politics and International Relations at the [[University of Warwick]], graduating with a BA in 2006.
==Business== In 2004, Aquarone co-founded media business Ephex Media Limited with two fellow students at the University of Warwick. Ephex Media received investment from the Advantage Early Growth Fund in 2007<ref>[http://issuu.com/thinkenterprise/docs/think_enterprise_case_study_booklet_sept2010 "Think Enterprise Case Studies"], 15 September 2010. Retrieved on 9 June 2012.</ref> in order to acquire regional post-production facility Oakslade Studios.<ref>[http://www.4rfv.co.uk/industrynews.asp?id=66561 "4RFV"], 2 October 2007. Retrieved on 9 June 2012.</ref> The company made and edited corporate films for brands including Land Rover, Vodafone, Massey Ferguson and American Express. The business was placed into administration in 2008.<ref>[http://www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/58772/notices/573262/all=ephex], ''[[The London Gazette]]'', 22 July 2008. Retrieved on 9 June 2012.</ref>
Aquarone co-owns feature film production company Immense Productions with author [[Guy Browning]],<ref>[http://www.birminghampost.net/birmingham-business/birmingham-business-news/creative-industries-news/2008/07/21/immense-get-a-funny-idea-about-business-65233-21376892/ "Immense get a funny idea about business"] ''[[The Birmingham Post]]'' 21 July 2008. Retrieved 9 June 2012.</ref> whose first feature ''[[Tortoise in Love]]'' on which Aquarone was producer<ref>IMDB [https://www.imdb.com/name/nm2412631/] "IMDB". Retrieved on 9 June 2012.</ref> released in the UK in 2012.<ref>British Board of Film Classification [http://www.bbfc.co.uk/AFF288660/ "Tortoise in Love"]. Retrieved on 9 June 2012.</ref>
In 2011, Aquarone co-founded peer-to-peer<ref>Cockburn, Russ [http://www.egovmonitor.com/node/48798 "How traditional banking is failing people technologically"] 4 April 2012. Retrieved 9 June 2012.</ref> mobile payments platform Droplet<ref>Crunchbase [http://www.crunchbase.com/company/settle "Droplet"]. Retrieved 9 June 2012.</ref> which allows users to load funds to an app on their mobile phones and send payments to other people or merchants.<ref>Birmingham Post [http://www.birminghampost.net/birmingham-business/birmingham-business-news/businesslatest/2012/03/31/birmingham-entrepreneurs-settle-launch-payment-app-for-smartphones-65233-30666766/ "Birmingham entrepreneurs launch payment app for smartphones"], ''[[The Birmingham Post]]'' 31 March 2012. Retrieved 9 June 2012.</ref>
In 2013, Droplet was named among the 'Top 25 UK Startups' by influential technology blog Mashable.<ref>[http://mashable.com/2013/06/27/uk-startups/] "25 Top UK Startups." Retrieved 9 May 2014.</ref>
==Writing== Aquarone writes on digital marketing topics including online video. In 2012 he wrote "Online Video: A Best Practice Guide" for digital publishers Econsultancy.<ref>[http://econsultancy.com/uk/reports/online-video-best-practice-guide "Online Video Best Practice Guide"], January 2012. Retrieved 9 June 2012.</ref>
==Politics==
On 4 May 2017, he was elected as county councillor for the [[Melton Constable]] division of [[Norfolk County Council]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Conservatives take control after results of Norfolk County Council elections, but UKIP and Greens wiped out|url=http://www.edp24.co.uk/news/politics/latest-election-results-in-Norfolk-and-Suffolk-county-council-elections-1-5004733|publisher=Eastern Daily Press|accessdate=5 May 2017}}</ref> He is deputy leader of the Liberal Democrat group on the council.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Scott|first1=Geraldine|title=Norfolk’s Liberal Democrats appoint new leadership team following local elections|url=http://www.thetfordandbrandontimes.co.uk/news/norfolk-s-liberal-democrats-appoint-new-leadership-team-following-local-elections-1-5006503|accessdate=24 September 2017|work=Thetford and Brandon Times|date=7 May 2017}}</ref>
==Personal life== Aquarone lives in Norwich with his wife, and is a practicing [[Quakers|Quaker]], involved in local politics with the Liberal Democrat party.
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Aquarone, Steffan Luke}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:British Quakers]] [[Category:British businesspeople]] [[Category:Members of Norfolk County Council]] [[Category:People educated at Norwich School (independent school)]]

{{Infobox book | name = The Strategy Paradox | title_orig = | translator = | image = The-Strategy-Paradox-Cover.jpg | caption = Cover of ''The Strategy Paradox'' | author = [[Michael E. Raynor]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | genre = [[Business|Business & Economics]] [[Management]] | publisher = [[Doubleday (publisher)|Doubleday]] | release_date = 2007 | english_release_date = | media_type = | pages = 320 pp | isbn = 978-0-385-51622-8 | isbn_note = (0-385-51622-3) | dewey= 658.4/012 22 | congress= HD30.28 .R384 2007 | oclc= 70778348 | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''The Strategy Paradox''''' is a [[business strategy]] book by author [[Michael E. Raynor]], who is the Distinguished Fellow with [[Deloitte]] Research. ''The Strategy Paradox'' was published in 2007 by [[Doubleday (publisher)|Currency/Doubleday]]. It was named a top ten book of 2007 by ''[[BusinessWeek]]'',<ref>http://images.businessweek.com/ss/07/11/1130_business_books/index_01.htm</ref> and a top five strategy book of 2007 by ''Strategy+Business''.<ref>http://www.strategy-business.com/press/article/07408c?pg=1</ref>
==Synopsis==
''The Strategy Paradox'', the title and focus of the book sets up a ubiquitous but little-understood tradeoff. The tradeoff is that most strategies are built on specific beliefs about an unpredictable future, but current strategic approaches force leaders to commit to an inflexible strategy regardless of how the future might unfold. It is this commitment to uncertainty that is the cause of "the strategy paradox."
==Reviews==
*''National Post'' '''With the right strategy, you can take big risks and win.''' By John Worsley Simpson, Financial Post [http://www.canada.com/nationalpost/story.html?id=0e464e31-a96c-448b-aeff-7053d7e9a595] *''BusinessWeek'' '''Sidstepping Disaster.''' By Dean Foust [http://www.businessweek.com/magazine/content/07_12/b4026106.htm?chan=search] *''The Financial Times'' '''Take a strategic risk but hedge your bets.''' By Fergal Byrne [http://www.ft.com/cms/s/f53891f0-cc50-11db-a661-000b5df10621.html] *''Boston Globe'' '''For CEOs, admitting uncertainty can be the key to success.''' By Robert Weisman [http://www.boston.com/business/globe/articles/2007/07/01/for_ceos_admitting_uncertainty_can_be_the_key_to_success/] *''Harvard Business Review'' By Anand P. Raman [http://harvardbusinessonline.hbsp.harvard.edu/hbsp/hbr/articles/article.jsp?_requestid=36546&ml_subscriber=true&ml_action=get-article&ml_issueid=BR0705&articleID=BooksInBrief&pageNumber=1]
== References ==
<references/>
==Further reading==
*Raynor, M. E. '''2005'''. ''Strategic Flexibility: Corporate-level Real Options as a Response to Uncertainty in the Pursuit of Strategic Integration.'' In Bower, Joseph L., and Clark Gilbert, eds., ''From Resource Allocation to Strategy'', UK, Oxford University Press. Chapter 14. *Raynor, Michael E. '''2002'''. ''Strategic Flexibility: Charting a Path Through Uncertainty.'' Convergence Magazine ([[South African]] edition), Vol. 2(4). *Raynor, Michael E. '''2002'''. ''Make Peace with Business Uncertainty.'' Optimize. August.
==External links== * [http://www.michaelraynor.com Website of author Michael E. Raynor] * [https://www.amazon.ca/dp/0385516223 The Strategy Paradox on Amazon] * [http://first.emeraldinsight.com/promo/raynor.htm Interview with Emerald Management First] * [http://www.iveybusinessjournal.com/article.asp?intArticle_ID=696 Interview with Ivey Business Journal]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Strategy Paradox}} [[Category:2007 books]] [[Category:Business books]] [[Category:Doubleday (publisher) books]]

{{Infobox person | name = Tomy Winata | image = Tomy_Winata.jpg | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Guo Shuo Feng 郭說鋒 | birth_date ={{Birth date and age|1958|07|23}} | birth_place = [[Jakarta]], [[Indonesia]] | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | nationality = [[Indonesia]]n | known_for = Owner and Chairman of Artha Graha Group Founder of Artha Graha Care Foundation ([[Artha Graha Peduli Foundation]]) | occupation = Entrepreneur, Philanthropist
}} '''Tomy Winata''' (pronounced {{IPA-id|ˈtomi wiˈnata|}} and sometimes misspelled as Tommy Winata); born '''Guo Shuo Feng 郭說鋒''' on 23 July 1958; is an [[Indonesia]]n businessman with interests in banking, property, gambling and infrastructure, whose wealth comes from his business deals for the [[Indonesian National Armed Forces|Indonesian Military]].<ref name="smh030509">{{cite web |url=http://www.smh.com.au/world/dili-tycoon-deal-triggers-alarm-20090502-aqtj.html | title=Dili tycoon deal triggers alarm |last1 = Murdoch |first1= Lindsay | last2 = Hyland | first2 = Tom |publisher=[[Sydney Morning Herald]]| date=3 May 2009 |accessdate=14 June 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tokohindonesia.com/daftar-tokoh/article/283-direktori/2054-tommy-winata | title=Tommy Winata: Artha Group Boss |author= |date= |work= |publisher=''Tokoh Indonesia'' |accessdate=2 June 2011|language=id}}</ref> His philanthropic interests include the environment,<ref>[http://finance.detik.com/read/2012/12/18/142317/2121446/4/kisah-tomy-winata-harimau-dan-lingkungan-hidup Wawancara Khusus CEO TWNC: Kisah Tomy Winata, Harimau dan Lingkungan Hidup], ''detik.com'', 18 December 2012.</ref><ref>[http://www.beritalingkungan.com/2013/01/ketika-tw-mendukung-konservasi-harimau.html Ketika TW Mendukung Konservasi Harimau], ''beritalingkungan.com'', 29 January 2013.</ref> particularly the [[Tambling Wildlife Nature Conservation]] a 45,000 hectare forest, endangered wildlife and sea conservation area, located in southern [[Sumatra]].
He is the son of an automobile spare parts trader and left school in the seventh grade upon which he sold ice pops to support his family. According to [[The Washington Post]], he then "rose from a car washer and office boy to become one of the nation's richest men". In 2006, he was listed as #35 on a [[Forbes]] list of "the 40 richest men in Indonesia".<ref name="forbes">{{cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/lists/2006/80/06indonesia_Tomy-Winata_RSXG.html |title=Indonesia's 40 Richest: #35 Tomy Winata |author= |date=7 September 2006 |work= |publisher=''Forbes'' |accessdate=2 June 2011}}</ref>
==Business career== Winata's business empire has been developed under the Artha Graha Group and Artha Graha Network. In 1988, he worked with the Indonesian Army Foundation to rescue a troubled local bank, Bank Propelat, and subsequently changed its name to Bank Artha Graha.{{citation needed|date=June 2013}} In mid-1997, in cooperation with [[Bank Indonesia]] he bailed out Bank Arta Prima,{{citation needed|date=June 2013}} which was then merged with Bank Artha Graha. In 2003, Artha Graha Group took over Bank Inter-pacific, Tbk (a publicly listed company).{{citation needed|date=June 2013}} In 2005, Bank Inter-pacific, Tbk acquired Bank Artha Graha becoming Bank Artha Graha Internasional, Tbk (INPC.JK).{{citation needed|date=June 2013}}
Winata is involved in the property sector through PT Jakarta International Hotels and Development, Tbk (JIHD.JK, a publicly listed company), which owns Borobudur Hotel in Central Jakarta, and PT Danayasa Arthatama, Tbk (SCBD.JK, a publicly listed company), which owns the Sudirman Central Business District (SCBD) in the heart of Jakarta.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://scbd.com/menu/page/profile | title = Profil | publisher = SCDB Company Profile | access-date = 8 January 2018 | language = Indonesian}}</ref> SCBD includes the Indonesian Stock Exchange Building. Winata plans to build the Signature Tower Building-Jakarta, a 111-storey skyscraper, which will be the fifth tallest building in the world, in the center of the SCBD. He has said the mega-project is part of his mission to show the world that "Indonesia can".<ref>[http://www.antarasumbar.com/berita/nasional/d/0/285152/tomy-winata-indonesia-jadi-pemain-penting-dunia.html Tomy Winata: Indonesia Jadi Pemain Penting Dunia] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131017020735/http://www.antarasumbar.com/berita/nasional/d/0/285152/tomy-winata-indonesia-jadi-pemain-penting-dunia.html |date=2013-10-17 }}, ''antarasumbar.com'', 23 April 2013.</ref> His vision is to make SCBD the "Manhattan of Indonesia".<ref>[http://www.thejakartaglobe.com/business/jakarta-can-be-a-new-manhattan-tomy-winata/587266 Jakarta Can Be a 'New Manhattan': Tomy Winata'] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130424000904/http://www.thejakartaglobe.com/business/jakarta-can-be-a-new-manhattan-tomy-winata/587266 |date=2013-04-24 }}, ''The Jakarta Post'', 22 April 2013.</ref><ref>[http://www.jurnas.com/news/90197/Jakarta_Bisa_Jadi_Kota_Yang_Diperhitungkan_Dunia/1/Nasional/Ibu_Kota Jakarta Bisa Jadi Kota Yang Diperhitungkan Dunia] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131017081107/http://www.jurnas.com/news/90197/Jakarta_Bisa_Jadi_Kota_Yang_Diperhitungkan_Dunia/1/Nasional/Ibu_Kota |date=2013-10-17 }}, ''jurnas.com'', 22 April 2013.</ref>
He is active in the infrastructure sector, through the company PT Bangungraha Sejahtera Mulia, which obtained support from the governors of [[Banten]] and [[Lampung]] provinces to be the lead investor for the [[Sunda Strait Bridge]]<ref>[http://ekbis.rmol.co/read/2013/04/23/107555/Pengusaha-Nasional-Dukung-Pembangunan-Jembatan-Selat-Sunda- Pengusaha Nasional Dukung Pembangunan Jembatan Selat Sunda], ''Rakyat Merdeka Online'', 23 April 2013.</ref><ref>[http://www.suarapembaruan.com/ekonomidanbisnis/tomy-winata-indonesia-bisa-buat-sejarah/34208 Wawancara CNBC 'Tomy Winata: Indonesia Bisa Buat Sejarah'], ''Suara Pembaruan Online'', 20 April 2013.</ref> project which, if it proceeds, will be the largest single infrastructure project ever undertaken in Indonesia.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://bisniskeuangan.kompas.com/read/2009/08/31/1953406/tomy.winata.didukung.gubernur.banten.dan.lampung |title=Tomy Winata Didukung Gubernur Banten dan Lampung |author= |date=31 August 2009 |work= |publisher=''Kompas'' |accessdate=2 June 2011|language=id}}</ref> Based on Indonesian Presidential Regulation Number 86, dated 2 December 2011, the Lampung-Banten consortium with PT Bangungraha Sejahtera Mulia was appointed to be the Project Initiator to work on a feasibility study for the Sunda Strait Bridge Project and Strategic Area Development.<ref>[http://www.rmol.co/read/2013/04/23/107567/Tomy-Winata:-Ground-Breaking-JSS-Sangat-Sulit-Dilakukan-Tahun-2014 Tomy Winata: Ground Breaking JSS Sangat Sulit Dilakukan Tahun 2014], ''Rakyat Merdeka Online'', 23 April 2013.</ref> Following the Presidential Regulation, Banten and Lampung provinces together with PT Bangun Sejahtera Mulia established a joint venture company called PT Graha Banten Lampung Sejahtera (GBLS) to conduct the Sunda Strait feasibility study. Based on its pre-feasibility study, Sunda Strait Project construction cost was estimated around US$10 billion and will take around 8 to 10 years to develop.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tempointeractive.com/hg/nasional/2010/11/02/brk,20101102-288905,uk.html |title=Consortium Teams Up with China to Build Sunda Strait Bridge |author= |date=2 November 2010 |work= |publisher=''Tempo'' |accessdate=2 June 2011}}</ref>
The Sunda Strait Bridge Project <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2012/07/05/us-bank-eyes-sunda-strait-bridge-project.html |title=US bank eyes Sunda Strait Bridge project |author= The Jakarta Post|date=5 July 2012 |work= |publisher=''The Jakarta Post'' |accessdate=}}</ref> has progressed from an "impossible dream" in 2002 to becoming "almost a possible reality" in 2012, but in 2014 new president [[Joko Widodo]] shelved the project.<ref name=Shelve2014>{{cite news|first=Satria|last=Sambijantoro|url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2014/11/03/no-more-sunda-strait-bridge-plan.html|title=No more Sunda Strait Bridge plan|work=The Jakarta Post|date=3 November 2014|accessdate=5 July 2017}} See also {{cite news|url=http://www.globalindonesianvoices.com/17165/new-government-will-not-prioritize-sunda-strait-bridge-project/|title=New Government Will Not Prioritize Sunda Strait Bridge Project|work=Global Indonesian Voices|date=2 November 2014|accessdate=5 July 2017}}</ref>
Winata also has business ventures outside of Indonesia, including in [[Timor Leste]], where he was given approval in secret to build a hotel and shopping complex on government-owned land without having to submit his bid to a tendering process.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thejakartaglobe.com/specialfeatures/the-land-that-indonesia-lost/437236 |title=The land that Indonesia lost |author=Joe Cochrane |date=25 April 2011 |work= |publisher=''The Jakarta Globe'' |accessdate=2 June 2011}}</ref><ref name="smh030509"/>
Besides his legal operations, Tomy is also a member of the so-called "nine dragons", a group comprising the major individuals behind Jakarta's gambling industry, despite the practice being banned in Indonesia.<ref name = "icw">{{Citation | author = Danang Widoyoko | author2 = Irfan Muktiono | author3 = Adnan Topan Husodo | author4 = Barly Harliem Noe | author5 = Agung Wijaya | title = Bisnis Militer Mencari Legitimasi (The Military's Business Seeks Legitimacy | language = Indonesian | publisher = [[Indonesia Corruption Watch]] | url = https://bukuicw.files.wordpress.com/2008/07/bisnis-militer-mencari-legitimasi_ind.pdf |accessdate=16 June 2016}}</ref>
Aside from his businesses, Winata has established a social non-profit foundation called [[Artha Graha Peduli Foundation]] (AG Peduli Foundation),<ref>[http://www.beritasatu.com/makro/109141-tomy-winata-bukan-kerajaan-bisnis-tapi-membangun-masyarakat-dan-lingkungan.html Tomy Winata: Bukan Kerajaan Bisnis Tapi Membangun Masyarakat dan Lingkungan], ''BeritaSatu.com'', 20 April 2013.</ref> which has five major social activities: provision of emergency relief to victims of natural disasters in Indonesia and abroad; humanitarian programs in food resilience, education and health; programs to save the environment; people empowerment through Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs); and provision of legal assistance for the underprivileged.
==Environmentalism== Winata runs a rescue center for the critically endangered [[Sumatran tiger]] in<ref name="The New York Times">{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/22/world/asia/22tigers.html?pagewanted=all&_r=1&|title=Trying to Save Wild Tigers by Rehabilitating Them |author= |date=21 April 2010 |work= |publisher=''The New York Times''}}</ref> Tambling Wildlife Nature Conservation, a park in [[Lampung Province]], Sumatra. Here he tries to reintroduce "[[conflict tigers]]"—tigers that have attacked or killed humans—into the wild.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://scotlandonsunday.scotsman.com/news/Indonesian-tycoon-Tomy-Winata-bids.6251813.jp |title=Indonesian tycoon Tomy Winata bids to save Sumatran tigers by release back into the wild |author=Norimitsu Onishi |date=25 April 2010 |work= |publisher=''Scotland on Sunday'' |accessdate=2 June 2011}}</ref> TWNC has released five Sumatran tigers back to the TWNC forest,<ref name="The Jakarta Post">{{cite web |url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2009/06/05/three-more-tigers-be-released-tambling-forest.html |title=Three more tigers to be released in Tambling forest |author= Oyos Saroso H.N.|date=5 June 2009 |work= |publisher=''The Jakarta Post''}}</ref> and was also able to release other protected wildlife and animals such as crocodiles and turtles. In addition to 45,000 hectares of forest, TWNC includes 14,500 hectares of sea conservation area.<ref>[http://www.kapanlagi.com/showbiz/hollywood/kylie-minogue-ketakutan-di-depan-gerbang-harimau.html Kylie Minogue Ketakutan di Depan Gerbang Harimau'], ''KapanLagi.com'', 5 July 2011.</ref>
Winata has cooperated with the [[National Anti-Narcotics Agency (Indonesia)|Indonesian Narcotics Agency]] (Badan Narkotika Nasional-BNN) to organize a [[drug rehabilitation]] <ref name="UNODC">{{cite web |url=http://www.unodc.org/southeastasiaandpacific/en/2012/12/ed-tambling-rehab/story.html|title=For an ecology of the mind: blending drug rehab with nature conservation in Sumatra |author= UNODC |date=8 December 2012 |work= |publisher=''UNODC''}}</ref> program in TWNC.<ref>[http://www.bisnis.com/photos/detail/10/bnn-gandeng-tomy-winata BNN Gandeng Tomy Winata] {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130616020027/http://www.bisnis.com/photos/detail/10/bnn-gandeng-tomy-winata |date=2013-06-16 }}, ''Bisnis.com'', 17 February 2013.</ref><ref>[http://www.bisnisindonesia.info/rehabilitasi-pecandu-narkoba-bnn-gandeng-tomy-winata Rehabilitasi Pecandu Narkoba: BNN Gandeng Tomy Winata]{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}, ''Bisnis Indonesia'', 17 February 2013.</ref> The program combines rehab and environmental conservation, encouraging former drug users to re-establish their lives and livelihoods through work in TWNC conservation and eco-tourism. This program was presented by Winata at the [[UNODC]] (United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime) 2013 Annual Meeting in Vienna, Austria.<ref>[http://www.investor.co.id/home/tomy-winata-paparkan-twnc-di-wina/56899 Tomy Winata Paparkan TWNC di Wina], ''Investor Daily'', 18 March 2013.</ref> UNODC's Executive Director, [[Yuri Fedotov]], expressed appreciation to Winata for the TWNC program, and said UNODC will encourage other countries to visit Tambling to study its drug rehabilitation program.
[[File:CR7_and_Tomy_WInata.jpg|thumb|left|Cristiano Ronaldo becomes ambassador for Mangrove Care Forum Bali]] In March 2013, in Madrid, Spain, Winata together with the Bali Mangrove Care Forum appointed "[[Cristiano Ronaldo]]" (CR7), the top Real Madrid soccer player, to be the Ambassador of Mangroves.<ref>[http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2013/03/17/ronaldo-ambassador-mangrove.html-0 Ronaldo ambassador for mangrove], ''The Jakarta Post'', 17 March 2013.</ref><ref>[http://sport.detik.com/sepakbola/read/2013/03/11/190212/2191834/424/cristiano-ronaldo-jadi-duta-pelestarian-mangrove-di-Indonesia Cristiano Ronaldo Jadi Duta Pelestarian Mangrove di Indonesia], ''detik.com'', 11 March 2013.</ref> Winata and Ronaldo agreed to conserve existing mangroves and plant new ones, especially in Bali surrounding areas.<ref>[http://www.thejakartaglobe.com/news/cr7-to-help-protect-bali-mangroves/ CR7 to Help Protect Bali Mangrove], ''Jakarta Globe'', 13 March 2013.</ref>
==The Press== In a high-profile case against the news magazine ''[[Tempo magazine (Indonesia)|Tempo]]'' following an article's "Ada Tomy in Tenebang?" (Is there Tomy in [[Tanah Abang]] ?) published in the March 3, 2003 issue of ''[[Tempo magazine (Indonesia)|Tempo]]'',<ref name="WP">{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A42646-2004Aug28.html |title=Magazine Case Tests Indonesian Press Freedom |author=Ellen Nakashima |date=29 April 2004 |work= |publisher=''The Washington Post'' |accessdate=2 June 2011}}</ref> ''Tempo'' editor-in-chief [[Bambang Harymurti]] was found guilty.<ref name="smh030509"/>
The Central Jakarta District Court ordered ''[[Tempo magazine (Indonesia)|Tempo]]'' magazine to publicly apologize and to pay a fine of 500 million rupiah (US$59,000). Tomy filed libel charges against PT Tempo Inti Media; chief editor Bambang Harymurti; chief deputy editor Toriq Hadad; reporters Ahmad Taufik, Bernarda Rurit, and Cahyo Junaidi; publisher Fikri Jufri and corporate director Zulkifli Lubis, according to a Tempo report.<ref>{{cite web|title=Magazine found guilty of libel|url=https://cpj.org/x/ec6|website=cpj.org|accessdate=March 18, 2004}}</ref> The presiding judge stated that, "Tempo failed to find the truth by covering both sides before publishing the article," said a report in [[The Jakarta Post]]. However, this conviction was later overturned on appeal.<ref name="smh030509"/>
In another high-profile case, in the provision of travellers cheques used in 2004 to bribe Indonesian politicians to elect Miranda Swaray Goeltom as Senior Deputy Governor in the Indonesian central bank, [[Bank Indonesia]], has been widely reported in the Indonesian media.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.asiasentinel.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=3189&Itemid=367 |title=Indonesia's Judicial Flying Circus |author= |date=12 May 2011 |work= |publisher=''Asia Sentinel'' |accessdate=2 June 2011}}</ref> Miranda said he did not know the owner of Bank Artha Graha. "Who owns it?" she told Tempo last Friday. "I do not know."<ref>{{cite web|title=Dekat dengan Bos Artha Graha? Ini Kata Miranda|url=https://nasional.tempo.co/read/news/2012/01/30/063380463/dekat-dengan-bos-artha-graha-ini-kata-miranda|website=nasional.tempo.co|publisher=Tempo.co|accessdate=30 January 2012}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
